text: Hello everyone. Hello mates. Thank you
all for coming today. It's always a
pleasure to be here unreal fest around
all the other passionate Unreal nerds
like myself. So welcome to my talk
enhancing digital to the twins
scriptable tools and design workflows
for crowds. Now allow me just to
introduce myself to you all before I get
started. So my name is Joseph Yong. I'm
the lead Unreal developer at Squint
Opera. Now I started my journey with
Unreal about 13 years ago now. So, I
started as a games artist and I went on
to become a gameplay programmer. And
it's this marriage between the te uh
technical and the creative that's really
shaped the way that I approach tasks
like building pipelines and tools and
applications with Unreal. And that's
really what today's talk is about. How
can we build tools that are going to
reduce friction, lower the barrier to
entry, and allow us to spend more time
focused on the creative tasks at hand
and less on the repetitive and the
remedial tasks that can come along with
production. So, as I said, I work at a
company called Squint Opera. We're a
sponsored service partner of what we're
very proud and allows me to be here to
talk to you all today. But Squint is
actually part of a larger collective
that's called Journey. And this is a
collaboration with many different
talented design agencies that work in
multiple different disciplines to create
experiences for their clients, which we
like to call multi-dimensional
experiences. Now, this can be anything
between stage shows to designing
museums, virtual production, and digital
twins. But we all live and breathe this
stuff and it's having access to leading
experts in all these different fields
that really allows us to innovate on
what we do. And Squint Opera as an
entity has been around for over 20 years
now. So we have an expansive body of
work in the cultural and the
architectural spaces. But it's the last
6 years or so we've had a real focus on
real time and interactive applications.
And it's Unreal Engine and digital twins
that have become our bread and butter at
the heart of it all. So this allows us
to build cool stuff every day. and some
of which I'm excited to share with you
all today. So just to get us started, I
want to just introduce some concepts and
some terminology so we're all on the
same page. And then I want to talk about
our approach to tools. So today with
scriptable tools, it's not about how to
build them in blueprints like many other
smarter people than me have already
built those talks. So what we're going
to talk about is our design approach and
how we approach the UX to make these
easy to use for all of our teams. And to
do this, I'm going to give you a little
demonstration of some tools we've been
building over the last year or two,
which focuses around creating optimized
crowd characters for our large open
scenes. And then finally, how you can do
this, too. So, I want everyone to have a
bit of a practical takeaway from this
today. So, there's an EDC post that I'm
putting up at the end of the week as a
companion post for this. And part of
that, there's going to be some assorted
resources for you all. So, there's going
to be a small code plugin that you can
get that has a couple of utilities you
can use to extend your own tools and
just push scriptable tools a little bit
further than what comes out of the box
for the editor. And then some resource
links. So, anything that I can't fully
get in depth with you all today, I'll
post some tutorial links and uh creators
and contributors that have been vital to
my own learning with Unreal Engine. So,
let's dive in and let's just say what is
a scriptable tool, right? So, just to
get a quick show of hands, how many
people here have actually built
scriptable tools?
Okay, so I've got a couple of dudes.
Most people hands are down. So, that's
good. I'm not redundant yet. So,
scriptable tool for the rest of you.
What it does, it takes the interactive
tools framework and exposes it to
blueprints for us. So, if you look at
the documentation, they point towards
the modeling toolkits, right? This is
what an interactive tool could be. This
isn't to say you get all of the geometry
and modeling tools with this, but what
it is is it's a framework that can sit
on top of more complex tasks you've
built and you have a nice easily
dockable tool that lives in your tool
pallet and it's just there to speed up
our workflows and make our lives easier.
So over the last couple of years where
we've adopted scriptable tools into our
pipeline, there's a number of benefits
that we've come into. So the first one
just being faster prototyping. So, as I
said, they've exposed this to blueprints
now. And the real advantage of visual
scripting from the beginning is just
it's quicker to get your ideas down,
right? We can hash this out, see what
works, and work with it very quickly.
And this leads in to broader
maintainability. So, exposing these uh
tools to the blueprints means that more
people are able to come in and actually
build tools for themselves. So,
previously you would have needed a team
of C++ coders to actually build these
custom tools on the back end, but now we
can have our tech artists pull this up
and build tools that are driven for
their own teams. And then finally, one
thing that I think is really important
with this is keeping your workflows in
the editor. Now, this isn't to say that
Unreal should or could do everything,
although we're very close to it, but
what it allows us to do is keep focused
on the task at hand. So, if we look back
when we all moved into UEIE5, there was
a big redesign of the UI. And a big part
of this was to keep you focused in the
viewport with what you're doing, give
you more screen space, stop us jumping
around different applications. We've all
been there, you know, like you got a
mesh, there's a hole. I've now got to
export that as an FBX and I'm going to
load another dcc. I'm not going to name
the name, but it takes like 10 minutes
to open. I'm going to patch the hole on
it and bring back in. And in that time,
all I've achieved is I've kind of wasted
my time, but I've broke that cognitive
flow. you know, it's taken me out of
what it is that I've been trying to do.
So, we're going to keep ourselves in the
editor and scriptable tools empower us
to do so. But although I love building
tools and frameworks, we should always
air on caution when we go to build these
things. We should consider ourselves,
right? So, there's a couple of questions
I always ask myself and my team when we
go to create these tools. So, the first
is just what problem are we trying to
solve? And really, this is saying, hey,
do your homework. Let's check out what
workflows already are documented and
exist. what plugins already in the
engine that we may be able to take uh
use of. Maybe it does 80% of what we
need it to, but we can use scriptable
tools as a framework to kind of massage
those inputs and outputs into exactly
what they need to be. So, let's not
reinvent the wheel. And then let's
always keep in mind who's going to use
this tool, like who is your end user. So
this isn't to like split the technical
and the creative people in the room, but
the way we look at problems can be very
different and the terminologies we use
can also be very different. So let's
make sure they're intuitive. A tool at
its heart should be simple and easy to
use and make our life easier. No one
wants to go and study for 20 minutes to
pick up a tool set that would should be
for a 30-second job. So let's make sure
it's very easy and well communicated.
And then finally, will it actually save
time? So this is something I've been
guilty of and I'm sure a few of you may
have done this too. You've got to scope
your time into the task that's at hand.
So for example, for us at Squint Opera,
we don't have the liberties of two,
three or four year long project
timelines. We work in more of a
quarterly basis with our clients. We
generally have about 2 to four months to
ship a project. So this means if we have
to factor in building a tool, it's not
just like, hey, I need 3 days to build
this. You need to QA this and make sure
it's good before it goes into
production. And also it must be
documented, right? This is the whole
point of a usable tool. And I would
argue if you don't do those last two
steps, you just have a fancy prototype
and you're the only person who knows how
to use it. So it defeats the point
there. So let's make sure we can scope
this all in and fit that in the window
we're doing. Now with all of that kind
of laid out, I think it's a good point
for us to start looking at this
character tool set. Let's have a little
bit more interest in. So given NDAs and
all the fun stuff that comes with
private sector work, I can't show you
our current production builds, but what
we've done instead is we've got a nice

Roman town. I'll link to it at the end,
but we've kit bashed together a scene to
give our characters some context. So you
can see how we lay out our characters,
the approach about where do we put
detail and why. So I've got a quick
version of it here for you all to see.
And we can see as it loads in here,
we're going to see
us overlooking a small plaza in a town.
And we have people animated on rooftops.
They're down in the cafes. We have
people walking through the scene,
introduce some motion. But what we try
to do to break up repetition of
characters is for example here where we
have a a painter and a family watching
them. We create what we call hero
animations to kind of break up that
repetition and add narrative story
beats. So we can do a bit of
environmental storytelling there. But as
we pan over to the left here, you'll
also see that we have cafes filled with
people. And these are entirely vertex
animation driven. So we've removed the
skeletons there and reduced that asset
size to allow us to do this at scale and
have many things going on on at once. So
you can see there the combination of
these. We layer them in in different uh
methods to allow us to get that final
pixel. So we know what we need to do. We
need to be able to give characters to
our clients. We need a set of tools to
do it. So we need to lay out just what
are the design goals. We need to make
this sustainable for ourselves. So first
of all, we need a consistent source for
these characters, right? There's many 3D
libraries out there, but they can be
wildly different in terms of their
visual fidelity and the topology that
you get with them, right? So we need
that one trustable source we can use
longterm. Then they need to be
customizable. We need them modular. We
work across many different world
cultures, so we need to make sure we can
dress them appropriately, especially if
we're representing certain events.
This one super important. They need to
be lightweight. We should all be aiming
for buttery smooth frame rates at all
times. So we need to make sure for us
working on district to cityscale
environments that we can support over a
thousand entities on screen and not be
harming our frame rates. And then
finally they need to be animated. So
this is kind of a bit of a stigma that
Archb has had for a long time where
everyone's kind of like pose statues and
nothing's happening. And this really
undermines the idea of it being real
time and interactive. Right? We're
trying to tell stories for our clients.
We often work with our clients in a
conceptual phase. So they want to
communicate the livability of a space
like how are humans going to interact in
this space. So we need to use animation
there to help give them some
environmental storytelling and do that
for them. So there's an elephant in the
room here which is the one source we can
get which is metahumans and how can we
leverage them for ourselves. So when we
started building this toolkit, it was
about two years ago and at the time
metahumans were still quite a cinematic
asset. They were quite heavy in terms of
their memory footprint. But in the last
two years, especially 55 and going into
56 like we saw yesterday, they're
incredibly more optimized. So they give
us a huge uh [clears throat]
wealth of a library to use, but we need
different levels of detail to scatter
these out for ourselves. Right? So for
me, when we were trying to
[clears throat]
map out this problem and how we're going
to go about it, it came down to one
answer, which was sandwiches. Now,
[clears throat] you got to bear with me
on this one cuz there is a method in a
madness. But basically, I was working
late trying [clears throat] to work out
how are we going to do this? And I
realized like, you know, when you're in
that kind of that flow state, you've
been programming, you go, "Hey, I
haven't eaten in 14 hours." So there I
was in like the cold, lonely darkness of

then it made me think, hey, I've got my
own modular hierarchy here and it's
interchangeable
[cough and clears throat]
and effectively I'm creating my own

meal. Right? So that's when I started

there we go. They're just the fridge,
right? So that's how we work with them
now. So we've got the body parts in an
interchangeable composition for
ourselves already. This is great.
They're modular for us." Yeah. So you
can see you have the torso, the legs,
the feet, but then we also have skeletal
meshes and grooms that build these up.
And within those they have their own
levels of detail, right? So we can
leverage geometry script to selectively
pull out what we need and recombine it
in other places. So you can think about
it as the shelves in a fridge as it
were. So with that idea, now we just
need to define what's our coverage
requirements like how are we going to
assess this at different levels of
detail. So for us in the foreground,
super easy answer, just use a metahuman.
The new optimized ones are excellent.
They've got facial animation. So if we
want to use mocap or we have voice over
that can do everything for us there. The
memory footprint is about a tenth of
what it used to be. So they're excellent
for that. But where we want to get into
those hundreds or thousands of people on
screen. We need to optimize a little bit
further. So this is where today's tool
set comes in. And as we get to the
midground, we have a merge down version
of a metum that we create. And this is
for our mass entity system and these
curated um hero animations that we do.
What we do with these is now we
selectively take those parts out of the
metahuman, recombine them into a single
skeletal mesh. So what we're doing here
is we're reducing the amount of scene
components, the amount of transform
updates we have per frame, but I'm also
removing the amount of bones we have. We
don't need this facial rig in them
anymore. So we're being selective about
that. And then finally, we're going to
merge down all of these material IDs
into a single texture atlas. So what we
do is we sacrifice a little bit of that
high-end visual fidelity to get a lot
more optimization on the other side. And
because they're midground actors, we can
make that sacrifice there. And then
finally, we have the mid to background.
And this is where we move over to vertex
animation. So at this point, there is a
trade-off where they become effectively
non-dynamic NPCs. These guys can't be
reactive to what happens at the scene
anymore because it's a baked animation.
But what this does do, it allows us to
take take the load off the CPU and move
all of this animation over to the GPU,
which reduces our asset size, but allows
it to run in parallel. So, at this
point, I think it's a good point for me
just to switch us over to the editor and
we can see how one of these tools works.

So it's a technique we're going to use
and we haven't pioneered it. It's been
around for years. It's been in games
design for ages and it's really powerful
where what we do is we take our
animation data from the CPU and we move
this over to the GPU where it can be a
lot faster and more efficient. So an
easy way to think about this is we have
threedimensional space. We have X, Y,
and Z or pitch, your roll for your
rotations. These are just floating point
values, right? These are scalar values.
So what we can do, we can map this over
to a linear color. They're a matching
data set, right? Although it's a color,
it is still just floating point values.
Now we have it as a linear color, we can
use this as a pixel in a texture. So
here we can now store this, cache that
in a texture, and that can be loaded
onto the GPU access later. So it becomes
very lightweight and it can run in
parallel. Now at this point that seems

think about your frameworks with a
bigger picture perspective. If you can
do some of the heavier lifting earlier
in that process so other tools can
benefit further down the line, do it
where you can. Reuse your resources as
much as possible. We want to be
efficient with memory management. We
don't want stutters. We want those
really nice frame rates. So be smart
about where we're loading things and if
we're repeating the same loads. And then
finally, as I've been talking about the
whole time, consider the UX of your
tools. A tool at its heart should make
your life easier. It should be simpler.
